{{Infobox university |name = University of NebraskaâLincoln |image = [[Image:Unlofficialseal.png|148px|Seal of the University of Nebraska]] |caption = University of Nebraska-Lincoln [[Seal (device)|seal]] |motto = ''Literis Dedicata et Omnibus Artibus'' |mottoeng = Dedicated to Letters and All the Arts |established = 1869 |type= [[Flagship#University campuses|Flagship]]
[[Public university|Public]]
[[Land-grant university|Land grant]] |calendar = Semester |endowment= [[United States Dollar|US $]]1.14 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]]{{Cite web| url=http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2010NCSE_Public_Tables_Endowment_Market_Values_Final.pdf | title=U.S. and Canadian Institutions Listed by Fiscal Year 2010 Endowment Market value and Percentage Change* in Endowment Market Value from FY 2010 to FY 2009 | publisher=National Association of College and University Business Officers and Commonfund Institute | year=2011 | accessdate=February 21, 2011|format=PDF}} |chancellor = Harvey Perlman |city = [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]] |state = [[Nebraska]] |country = [[United States|US]] |coor = {{Coord|40|49|03|N|96|42|05|W|type:edu_region:US-NE|display=inline,title}} |faculty = 1,597 |students = 24,593{{Cite web|url=http://irp.unl.edu/dmdocuments/fb11_12.pdf|title=University of NebraskaâLincoln Factbook 2011-2012|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln|accessdate=7 September 2011|location=Lincoln, NE}} |undergrad = 19,345 |postgrad = 4,679 |mascot= [[Herbie Husker]] and [[Lil' Red]] |campus = {{convert|613|acre|ha}},
{{convert|42562|acre|ha}} total throughout state |nickname= [[Nebraska Cornhuskers|Cornhuskers]] |colors = [[Scarlet (color)|Scarlet]] and [[Cream (color)|Cream]]
{{color box|#FF2400}} {{color box|#FFFDD0}} |athletics = [[NCAA]] [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] [[Football_Bowl_Subdivision#Football_Bowl_Subdivision|FBS]]
[[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]]
21 varsity teams |website = [http://www.unl.edu/ unl.edu] |logo = [[Image:USA ne UNLlogo.png|150px|University of Nebraska-Lincoln logo]] }} The '''University of NebraskaâLincoln''' (commonly referred to as '''Nebraska''', '''UNL''' or '''NU''') is a [[public university|public]] research [[university]] located in the city of [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Nebraska]].{{Cite web|url=http://classifications.carnegiefoundation.org/lookup_listings/view_institution.php?unit_id=181464|title=Carnegie Classifications - University of Nebraska|publisher=Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|accessdate=6 September 2010}} It is the state's oldest and largest university and the flagship university of the [[University of Nebraska system]]. The university was chartered by the legislature in 1869 as a [[land-grant university]] under the 1862 [[Morrill Act]], two years after Nebraska's statehood into the [[United States]]. Around the turn of the 20th century, the university began to expand significantly, hiring professors from [[East Coast of the United States|eastern]] schools to teach in the newly organized [[Professional schools|professional colleges]] while also producing groundbreaking research in agricultural sciences. The "Nebraska method" of ecological study developed here during this time, which pioneered grassland ecology and laid the foundation for research in [[theoretical ecology]] for the rest of the 20th century.{{Cite journal|last=Vandervoort|first=Frances|year=1999|title=A Green Centennial|journal=The American Biology Teacher|publisher=University of California|volume=61|issue=9|pages=648â659|jstor=4450796}}{{Cite book|last=Merchant|first=Carolyn|title=The Columbia Guide to American Environmental History|url=http://books.google.com/?id=bcdo0qlS0awC|accessdate=September 9, 2010|year=2005|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=Manhattan, NY|isbn=9780231112338|pages=163Ã¢ÂÂ164|chapter=Chapter 9: The Rise of Ecology 1890-1990}} The university is organized into eight colleges, located on two campuses in Lincoln with over 100 classroom buildings and research facilities.{{Cite web|url=http://historicbuildings.unl.edu/overview.html|title=UNL Historic Buildings - Historical Overview|year=2005|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln|accessdate=5 September 2010|location=Lincoln, NE}} Its athletic program, called the [[Nebraska Cornhuskers|Cornhuskers]], is a member of the [[Big Ten Conference]]. The UNL football team has won 46 conference championships and five [[College football national championships in NCAA Division I FBS|national championships]] since 1890. The women's volleyball team has won three [[NCAA Women's Volleyball Championship|national championships]] along with eight other appearances in the [[NCAA Women's Volleyball Championship|Final Four]].{{Cite web| url = http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&SPID=23&SPSID=18| title = Nebraska volleyball history | publisher = NU Athletics | accessdate = September 5, 2010}} The Husker football team plays its home games at [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], selling out every game since 1962. The stadium's current capacity is about 85,000 people, larger than the population of Nebraska's [[Bellevue, Nebraska|third-largest city]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.huskers.com//pdf5/40179.pdf?ATCLID=2722&SPSID=8&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100|title=Husker Football History|accessdate=2010-09-05|publisher=Huskers.com}}{{Cite web| url=http://www.huskers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=100&ATCLID=734 | title=Memorial Stadium - Home of the Huskers | publisher=Huskers.com | year=2010 | accessdate=September 5, 2010}} ==History== ===Origin=== The University of Nebraska was created by an act of the [[Nebraska Legislature|Nebraska state legislature]] in 1869, two years after [[Nebraska]] reached statehood. The school was given a mission to "afford to the inhabitants of the state the means of acquiring a thorough knowledge of the various branches of literature, science, and the arts." The school received an initial land grant of about {{convert|130000|acre|ha}} and the campus construction began with the building of University Hall in its first year. By 1873, the University of Nebraska had offered its first two degrees to its first graduating class.Pound, Louise. ''Semi-centennial Anniversary Book.'' Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. 1919. pp. 11-19. The school remained small and suffered from a lack of funds until about 20 years after its founding, when its high school programs were taken over by a new state education system. From 1890 to 1895 enrollment rose from 384 to about 1,500. A law school and a graduate school were also created at about this time period, making it the first school west of the Mississippi to establish a graduate school.This does not mean that UNL was the first school west of the Mississippi to issue a graduate degree. That honor belongs to the [[Washington University in St. Louis]]. UNL was, however, the first school in the region to formally organize a school for graduates. [http://www.unl.edu/ucomm/chancllr/] [http://www.unl.edu/unlpub/bulletin_grad/downloads/gradbulletin0507.pdf] [http://www.asdu.ait.ac.th/NewsAndEvents/bulletinByIssue.cfm?Date=18-Jun-2002] [http://www.fulbrighter.org/file_depot/0-10000000/20000-30000/21647/folder/49307/FAST200510.html] [http://bulletin.unl.edu/graduate/General_Information][http://graduateschool.wustl.edu/welcom/history] By 1897, the school was 15th in the nation in total enrollment.Luebke, Frederick. ''Nebraska: an Illustrated History.'' Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 2005. pp.172-3 ISBN 0803280424 Through the turn of the 20th century, the school struggled to find an identity as both a pragmatic, frontier establishment and an academic, intellectual institution.Knoll, Robert. ''Prairie University.'' Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1995. pp. 38-39. ISBN 0803227175 It also developed a competitive spirit in the form of a debate team, a football team (first called the Cornhuskers in 1901), and the arrival of fraternities and sororities.Knoll, Robert. ''Prairie University.'' Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1995. pp. 43-44 ISBN 0803227175 In 1913-14, a fierce debate ensued over whether to keep the University in downtown Lincoln or to move it out of town. The issue was not resolved until a statewide referendum sided with the downtown plan. After purchasing property downtown, the school experienced a building boom, both on the new property and on the farming campus. The school would not experience another boom until the late 1940s, when the sudden arrival of thousands of soldiers returning from the war for an education forced the school to seek further expansion.http://historicbuildings.unl.edu/overview.html ==Administration and organization== ===Organizations=== ====Governing bodies==== University of Nebraska is governed by the Board of Regents. The board consists of eight voting members elected by district for six-year terms, and four non-voting student Regents, one from each campus, who serve during their tenure as student body president. The board supervises the general operations of the university, and the control and direction of all expenditures. ====Faculties and schools==== The university today has nine faculties which offers more than 150 undergraduate majors, 20 pre-professional programs, 100 graduate programs and 275 programs of studyhttp://www.unl.edu/ucomm/depts/ * [[College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources]] * [[College of Architecture (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Architecture]] * [[College of Arts and Sciences (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Arts and Sciences]] * [[College of Business Administration (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Business Administration]] * [[College of Education and Human Sciences (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Education and Human Sciences]] * [[College of Engineering (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Engineering]] * [[Hixson-Lied College of Fine and Performing Arts]] * [[College of Journalism and Mass Communications (University of NebraskaâLincoln)|College of Journalism and Mass Communications]] * [[University of NebraskaâLincoln College of Law|College of Law]] UNL also offers programs at its campus from other University of Nebraska institutions, including the [[University of Nebraska at Omaha]] College of Public Affairs and Community Service, the [[University of Nebraska Medical Center]] colleges of Dentistry and Nursing, and the [[Peter Kiewit Institute]] managed in partnership with the University of Nebraska at Omaha. ==Campus== [[Image:University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Hamilton Hall.jpg|thumb|right|Hamilton Hall]] In 1869, the original University of Nebraska campus was laid out on four city blocks and comprised one building called University Hall. Currently, the university has two campuses, totalling {{convert|2815|acre|ha}}: City Campus, which is just north of downtown Lincoln, and south of the old [[Nebraska State Fair]] grounds and East Campus which is approximately two miles east-northeast of City Campus. Both the campus has an institute area, as well as a residential area. The institute area, consist of the departments, headquarters, governing body, research institutes, well equipped laboratories, theaters, auditoriums, recreation centers, fraternity and sorority housing, power plants, facilities and managements. Institute area occupies {{convert|613|acre|ha}} combining both the campuses. However the larger part is the residential district, which consist of student housing, residential apartments, and on campus living for faculties in apartments or individual cottages. Water supply management located in the residential district, supplies water throughout the campus. Remote sensing located in East campus,rail management factory in city campus, and some other remote research centers on telecommunications and wireless technology are also located in residential districts of the campus. Parks and recreation places inside the UNL city campus and East campus is a part of the residential area of the university. Other than the two main campuses, UNL also secures the honor of having UNL technology park located off campus, toward the northern side of Lincoln, at the Superior Street. The park covers an area of {{convert|25|acre|ha}}. It is supplied by some modern high tech laboratories on artificial intelligence.Nebraska Technology Park is the first endeavor of its kind in the state. The Technology Park was launched in 1997 as a joint effort of the University of Nebraska, private sector investors and the University of Nebraska Foundation. The purpose of the Technology Park is to promote synergies between the university and park companies in order to increase joint efforts in collaboration, discovery, and technology development. ===Major campus expansion=== In January 2010, the university acquired a {{convert|249|acre|ha|adj=on}} property north of city campus that formerly was used to host the Nebraska State Fair.{{Cite web|url=http://innovate.unl.edu/overview_vision.shtml|title=University of Nebraska Innovation Campus: Overview and Vision|accessdate=2011-08-02|publisher=unl.edu/overview_vision.shtml.com}} Plans for redevelopment include an [[United States Dollar|US $]]800 [[1000000 (number)|million]] expansion called the [[Nebraska Innovation Campus]], which is designated to house agricultural biotechnology and other life science research.{{Cite web|url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/education/article_00bde850-d5f8-11de-bfe2-001cc4c002e0.html|title=University of Nebraska Board of Regents approve Innovation Campus|accessdate=2011-08-02|publisher=JounralStar.com}}{{Cite web|url=http://newsroom.unl.edu/releases/2008/07/11/Nebraska+Innovation+Campus+ideas,++approaches+sought|title=Nebraska Innovation Campus|accessdate=2011-08-02|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln}} ===Unions=== [[Image:Nebraska Union.jpg|thumb|right|Nebraska Union]] Nebraska Union is the student union located on the southern part of City Campus. Many services are offered to the students including dining, computer labs, and other recreational activities, while the lower level of the union houses the University Bookstore. The Nebraska Union also provides space for student organizations, and events and speakers, as well as holding offices for the [[Daily Nebraskan]] and the student government. The Union is home to the Greek Affairs office and the Women's Center. The Rotunda Gallery showcases various student artwork. In spring 2006, the student body voted to finance an expansion to the Nebraska Union including adding new space for the university Culture Center (formerly in a different building).{{Cite web|url=http://newsroom.unl.edu/releases/2006/09/07/Perlman+announces+union+expansion%2C+international+study+progr|title=Perlman announces union expansion, international study program|date=2006-09-07|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln|accessdate=2008-09-22}} Nebraska East Union is located on East Campus and offers similar student services as the Nebraska Union. The Loft Gallery provides space for community and student artwork. ===Performing arts venues=== * The [[Lied Center for Performing Arts]] is a [[performing arts]] venue used primarily for orchestra concerts and theatre performances. The [[Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center]] is a two screen theater located on the UNL City Campus. It features primarily [[arthouse]] and [[independent films]], and [[documentaries]]. The Howell Theatre, Studio Theatre, and Lab Theatre are home to the performances of the Johnny Carson School of Theatre and Film. ===Other points of interest=== * Architecture Hall, formerly the universities' library and now home of the universities' outstanding architecture program, is a proud landmark standing on the west edge of campus. It is also the oldest building on campus. This historic structure is linked to the old law building via a huge glass connecting space, known, understandably, as "The Link." * Since the early 1920s UNL has been the home of the Headquarters of the National Society of [[Pershing Rifles]] a military fraternal organization for college-level students. This is in recognition of General [[John J. Pershing]] (an 1893 NU law school graduate and former professor of Military Science and Tactics) who created "Company A," a competitive drill team, for the University of Nebraska's Cadet Corps in 1891. The drill team won the National Competitive Drills in 1892, changed its name to the "Varsity Rifles" when it became a recognized fraternal organization in 1893, and finally changed its name again to the "Pershing Rifles" in 1894. UNL rededicated the Military and Naval Science Building as the John J. Pershing Military and Naval Science Building on April 20, 2006. * The [[International Quilt Study Center]] is on East Campus and will be [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] certified. * The Maxwell Arboretum located on East Campus is part of the [[Nebraska Statewide Arboretum]]. *There are several research centers on Physics like the [[DeWitt Bristol Brace|Brace]] Laboratory, Center of Materials and Nanoscience, High equipped laboratories are provided in Hamilton Hall which is the department as well and Chemistry institute. Othmer Hall houses the College of Engineering Dean's Office, the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, and the Biological Process Development Facility (BPDF). Research in Othmer Hall's Mesoscale Engineering Laboratory has received attention in ''Science''. Some highly equipped laboratories such as the Genetic research and Biotechnology laboratory are located on East Campus. *University is renowned also in Robotics. It has a high equipped robotics laboratory. *East Campus also has a wireless telecommunication system on remote sensing of Satellites. ==Academics== {{Infobox US university ranking | GUR = | ARWU_W = 152-200 | ARWU_N = 71-90 | ARWU_SCI = | ARWU_ENG = | ARWU_SOC = | USNWR_NU = 96 | USNWR_Bus = | USNWR_Law = | USNWR_Medr = 71 Research,Primary = 14 | USNWR_Eng = | USNWR_Ed = | THES_W = | Wamo_NU = 146 | Forbes = 442 | URAP_W = 317 }} ===Admissions and demographics=== The University of NebraskaâLincoln admitted about 67% of all applicants in 2008, and 68% of those admitted went on to enroll at the school. In 2007, the ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'' rated it as a "more selective" university.http://rankings.usnews.com/college/items/2565 On a 25th percentile/75th percentile measurement, students scored 500/650 on the SAT critical reading section and 530/670 on the math section. ACT composite scores were 22/28.http://collegeapps.about.com/od/collegeprofiles/p/nebraska.htm Eighty-five percent of undergraduates are white, with a little over 53% being male, and 47% being female.{{Cite web |title=Nebraska (NE): Overview of Nebraska's Colleges and Universities |url=http://education-portal.com/articles/Nebraska_(NE):_Overview_of_Nebraska's_Colleges_and_Universities.html }} About 18% of undergraduate students are from outside the state of Nebraska (excluding internationals). The ratio of students to faculty in 2008 was 20 to 1.http://irp.unl.edu/dmdocuments/CDS2008-09.pdf The school is in the first tier and ranked 104th in the ''U.S. News and World Report'''s national rankings.http://rankings.usnews.com/college/national-search/page+4 The university has been recorded as an A grade university throughout the world by '' University Ranking by Academic Performance(URAP)and acquires a rank of 317 by URAP and 152-200 by Academic Ranking of World Universities(ARWU)'' world rankings.http://www.urapcenter.org/2010/university.php?q=University+of+Nebraska+Lincoln world ranking.http://www.arwu.org/ARWU2010.jsp ===Research=== University of NebraskaâLincoln scientists have been some of the most-cited in the world in the last 10 years in the area of agricultural research, according to the IS1 Essential Science Indicators Report. Scientists in the UNL Institute of Agriculture and Natural Resources (IANR) alone published 1,028 papers, which were cited 6,056 times from January 1994 through January 2004.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unl.edu/resources/documents/customized_review_preliminary_submission.pdf|title=UNL Profile|date=2005-05-19|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln|accessdate=2011-07-21}} ===University libraries and museums=== [[Image:Don L. Love Memorial Library.jpg|thumb|right|170px|The Don L. Love Memorial Library is the main library in the University of Nebraska-Lincoln library system.]] The University Libraries are the only set of comprehensive research libraries in Nebraska. Three and half [[million]] volumes reside in UNL's two main libraries. The Don L. Love Memorial Library is the main library on campus and houses collections on [[social sciences]] and [[humanities]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.unl.edu/libr/about/|title= About UNL Libraries|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Libraries|accessdate=2008-09-22}} Other academic disciplines are housed in six branch locations on campus: * Architecture Library * C.Y. Thompson Library * Engineering Library * Geology Library * Mathematics Library * Music Library The Marvin and Virginia Schmid Law Library serves the UNL College of Law. [[Image:International Quilt Study Center & Museum Lincoln NE.jpg|thumb|right|International Quilt Study Center and Museum]] The [[University of Nebraska State Museum]] is located on campus in Morrill Hall. The museum holds several collections and exhibits particularly featuring [[natural history]] and famously houses [[Mammoth]] bone [[fossils]]. Because of these fossils, and a large bronze Columbian Mammoth statue located in front of the building, it is popularly known as "Elephant Hall." The [[Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery]] and Sculpture Garden is home to more than 12,000 works of art in all media and is a comprehensive collection of [[American art]] with prominent holdings in 19th century landscape and [[still life]], [[American Impressionism]], early [[Modernism]], geometric abstraction, [[Abstract Expressionism]], [[pop art|pop]], [[minimalism]], and [[contemporary art]]. The museum has the largest collection of 20th Century North American art in the world; it includes works by such well known artists as [[Edward Hopper]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Jackson Pollock]], [[Mary Cassatt]], [[Wayne Thiebaud]] and [[Georgia O'Keeffe]]. The [[Great Plains Art Museum]] is home to the Christlieb Collection, and features American western art and Americana. {{Cite web|url= http://www.unl.edu/plains/gallery/gallery.shtml |title= Great Plains Art Museum |work= Center for Great Plains Studies official website |quote= The Great Plains Art Museum opened in 1981 after a generous donation from Dr. John and Elizabeth Christlieb of Bellevue, Nebraska. The Christlieb Collectionâ¦ consists of approximately 170 bronze sculptures, 140 paintings and drawings, 100 other works on paper and several hundred photographs, and includes artwork by [[Albert Bierstadt]], [[William de la Montagne Cary]], [[Robert F. Gilder]], [[William Henry Jackson]], [[Frederic Remington]], [[Charles M. Russell]] and [[Olaf Wieghorst]]. The library donated by the Christliebs is an impressive 4,000 volumes, which consists of several Western novels and many other fiction and nonfiction books about the West and the Great Plains. }} The [[Lester F. Larsen Tractor Museum]] is located on the university's East Campus. It houses 40 historical tractors, an antique auto and various types of farm tools. In addition it documents [[Tractor#Nebraska tractor tests|Nebraska's tractor testing law examinations]] that to this day requires testing of all tractors to be sold in Nebraska, ensuring performance is as advertised. ===Focus areas=== The University's English Department has one of the world's top programs in the [[digital humanities]], with renowned digital archiving projects such as the [[Walt Whitman]] Archive and the [[Willa Cather]] Archive. Projects are also underway for the production of a free online Native American [[Omaha-Ponca language]] dictionary.http://stories.nufoundation.org/node/467 In the area of [[creative writing]], the department has as a member of its faculty former [[United States Poet Laureate]], [[Ted Kooser]].http://www.americanlifeinpoetry.org/kooser.html The school's [[University of Nebraska Press]] is the second-largest public university press in the United States, and is among the largest publishers of scholarly titles in the world.http://www.nufoundation.org/Shop//showDivision.sp?cat=87 ===AAU membership and removal=== In 1908, Nebraska was inducted as the 18th member of the [[Association of American Universities]], the organization of the nation's top research universities.{{Cite book|last=Knoll|first=Robert E.|title=Prairie University: a History of the University of Nebraska|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QtVFWVTRDGIC|accessdate=6 September 2010|date=1995-08-01|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|location=Lincoln|isbn=978-0803227170|pages=47â54|chapter=The Pattern of the Modern University}} [http://books.google.com/books?id=QtVFWVTRDGIC&lpg=PP1&vq=AAU&pg=PA48 Excerpt available] at [[Google Books]]. In recent years, Nebraska had been at or near the bottom of the AAU's statistical criteria for members, a ranking attributed in part to the university's extensive agricultural research funded by the [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]], which is not included in the AAU's rankings because it is not awarded by peer-reviewed grants; and because Nebraska's [[University of Nebraska Medical Center|medical school]] is a separate institution whose research funding is not under UNL's auspices. Nebraska successfully retained its AAU membership after a 2000 challenge. This provided Nebraska with an advantage when the [[Big Ten]] was looking to expand in 2010, as all of its members at that time were AAU members. Nebraska Chancellor Harvey Perlman said. "I doubt that our application would've been accepted had we not been a member of the [AAU]."{{cite news| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-06-13/sports/ct-spt-0614-aau-big-ten-expansion--20100613_1_aau-nebraska-chancellor-harvey-perlman-big-ten-members | work=Chicago Tribune | first=Chris | last=Hine | title=Nebraska has it all to attract Big Ten, most importantly AAU membership | date=2010-06-13}} However, in 2011, after an extended campaign to retain its membership and a close, contentious vote, Nebraska became the only institution to be removed from the AAU membership by a vote of the membership (a few other institutions had voluntarily resigned.){{cite news | first = Kevin | last = Abourezk | title = Research universities group ends UNL's membership | date = 2011-04-29 | url = http://journalstar.com/news/local/education/article_d9eca939-b681-535d-ad1a-a98d9ef3b01e.html?utm_campaign=ljtweet&utm_source=ljtweet&utm_medium=ljtweet | work = [[Lincoln Journal Star]] | accessdate = 2011-05-04}}{{cite news | first = Leslie | last = Reed | title = Academic group drops UNL | date = 2011-04-30 | url = http://www.omaha.com/article/20110429/NEWS01/110428852/1006415 | work = [[Omaha World-Herald]] | accessdate = 2011-05-04}}{{cite news | first = Tamar | last = Lewin | title = American Universities Group Votes to Expel Nebraska | date = 2011-05-02 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/03/education/03aau.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = 2011-05-04}}{{cite news | first = Jeffrey J. | last = Selingo | coauthors = Jack Stripling | title = Nebraska's Ouster Opens a Painful Debate Within the AAU | date = 2011-05-02 | url = http://chronicle.com/article/Ouster-Opens-a-Painful-Debate/127364/ | work = [[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] | accessdate = 2011-05-04}} ==Sustainability== The University of Nebraska has adopted [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] certification for all new construction projects. UNL's Sustainable Food Project, started in 2005, is designed to serve meals on campus that feature locally and sustainably produced foods. The university's motor pool includes vehicles fueled by soy biodiesel as well as gasohol (85% ethanol, 15% gasoline blend). The University of Nebraska received a grade of C on the College Sustainability Report Card 2011.{{cite web|title=University of NebraskaâLincoln Report Card 2011|url=http://www.greenreportcard.org/report-card-2011/schools/university-of-nebraska-lincoln|publisher=Sustainable Endowments Institute|accessdate=2 November 2010|year=2010}} As of 2009, the University's cafeterias no longer provide trays to the students, a program implemented to reduce organic waste and save money. ==Athletics== [[Image:University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg|thumb|left|80px|Athletic logo]] {{Main|Nebraska Cornhuskers}} [[File:091507-USCNeb-MemorialStadium.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A football game at [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]]]] Nebraska's [[college athletics|sports]] teams are nicknamed as the [[Cornhuskers]] (or simply the Huskers). They participate in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] (Division I FBS for football) in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] as members of the [[Big Ten Conference]]. The Huskers have 21 [[varsity team]]s that compete in 14 different sports and claim all or part of 23 National Championships across five sports, including volleyball, football, and gymnastics. In football, the Huskers have had three [[Heisman Trophy]] winners: [[Johnny Rodgers]], [[Mike Rozier]], and [[Eric Crouch]], along with five [[College football national championships in NCAA Division I FBS|national championship]] victories in 1970, 1971, 1994, 1995, and 1997. The football team holds multiple collegiate football records, including the longest collegiate football sell-out streak of 311 home games and the longest opening game winning streak of 25 victories as of September 2010.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} The team has won over 800 games total since 1890, a feat only shared by six other universities in the [[NCAA Division I]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} In 2007, [[Sarah Pavan]] received the Honda Award as the nation's top female student-athlete. ==Song== Notable among a number of songs commonly played and sung at various events such as [[Graduation|commencement]] and [[convocation]], and athletic games are ''Dear Old Nebraska U.'' and the University of NebraskaâLincoln fight song, ''Hail Varsity''. In Nebraska, the lyrics and music to ''Dear Old Nebraska U.'' are attributed to Harry Pecha, a 1924 Nebraska graduate.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unl.edu/band/songs.shtml |title=UNL Band fight songs |accessdate=2007-12-02 |publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln}} However, other schools and locales across the United States - including the [[University of Chicago]], the [[University of Florida]], and the [[Toledo, Ohio]] public school system - sing similar tunes, often with [[We are the Boys|similar lyrics]].[http://www.gainesville.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20051009/COLUMNS04/51009002/-1/COLUMNIST04 F-L-O-R-I-D-A, or is it T-O-L-E-D-O? - The Gainesville Sun] ==Student life== About 78 percent of UNL students are from Nebraska, while the rest are from all forty-nine other states and 114 foreign countries. On-campus students are also members of the UNL [[Residence Hall Association]], which serves as the governing body for the residence halls. Select honorary seniors include the Nebraska-only [[Society of Innocents]] and the Black Masque chapter of [[Mortar Board]]. ===Residence Halls=== [[File:EstherKauffmanSouth.jpg|thumb|250px|The Esther L. Kauffman Academic Residential Center.]] Approximately 40% of the student body lives on-campus in 14 traditional [[residence hall]]s, and two on-campus apartment-style halls (The Village and The Courtyards). There are 12 traditional residence halls on the City Campus: {{Columns-list|2| * Abel * Cather * Harper * Husker Hall * Kauffman Center * Knoll * Pound * Neihardt * Sandoz * Schramm * Selleck * Smith }} Three traditional residence halls are on the East Campus: Burr, Fedde, and Love Memorial Co-op. Three on-campus apartment-style halls are located on the City Campus: The Courtyards, The Village, and Robert E. Knoll Residential Center ===Student government=== The governing body for UNL students is the Association of Students of the University of Nebraska (ASUN). Every year students vote for a president, two vice presidents, and a senate that is composed of representatives from each college. The president also acts as the student regent to the NU Board of Regents. ===Student organizations=== UNL has around 400 student organizations on campus that represent a variety of interests.{{cite web|title=UNL {{!}} Student Involvement {{!}} Student Organizations {{!}} Resources and Tools|url=http://involved.unl.edu/organizations/|accessdate=10 December 2010}} Organizations are supported by Student Involvement. ===Greek Organizations=== UNL has a significant [[Fraternities and sororities|Greek population]], with about 5,200 students being members of 30 fraternities (28 chapters and two colonies) and 15 sororities. There are numerous events on campus throughout the year such as decorating "Greek Row" for the homecoming parade and various philanthropy events. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" !colspan=1|Sororities !colspan=2|Fraternities |- |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| * [[Alpha Chi Omega]] * [[Alpha Delta Pi]] * [[Alpha Omicron Pi]] * [[Alpha Phi]] * [[Alpha Xi Delta]] * [[Chi Omega]] * [[Delta Delta Delta]] * [[Delta Gamma]] * [[Gamma Phi Beta]] * [[Kappa Alpha Theta]] * [[Kappa Delta]] * [[Kappa Kappa Gamma]] * [[Phi Mu]] * [[Pi Beta Phi]] * [[Sigma Lambda Gamma]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| * [[Sigma Chi]] * [[Acacia Fraternity]] * [[Alpha Gamma Nu]] * [[Alpha Gamma Rho]] * [[Alpha Gamma Sigma (fraternity)|Alpha Gamma Sigma]] * [[Alpha Phi Alpha]] * [[Alpha Tau Omega]] * [[Beta Sigma Psi]] * [[Beta Theta Pi]] * [[Chi Phi]] * [[Delta Tau Delta]] * [[Delta Upsilon]] * [[FarmHouse]] * [[Iota Phi Theta]] * [[Kappa Alpha Psi]] * [[Kappa Sigma]] * [[Lambda Chi Alpha]] * [[Omega Psi Phi]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| * [[Phi Delta Theta]] * [[Pershing Rifles]] * [[Phi Gamma Delta]] * [[Phi Kappa Theta]] * [[Phi Kappa Psi]] * [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] * [[Pi Kappa Phi]] * [[Pi Tau Sigma]] * [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] * [[Sigma Lambda Beta]] * [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] * [[Sigma Nu]] * [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] * [[Theta Chi]] * [[Theta Xi]] |} ===Media=== The ''[[Daily Nebraskan]]'', known to students as the "DN", is UNL's student newspaper. It was established in 1901 and is published every weekday during the fall and spring semesters and weekly during the summer. UNL operates a [[list of broadcast station classes|Class A]] [[FM broadcasting|FM]] [[radio station]], [[KRNU]], which broadcasts on 90.3 FM and has a range of approximately {{convert|20|mi|km}}. The station plays mostly [[alternative music|alternative]] and [[modern rock]] as well as running sportscasts of Nebraska's home events, news, live public affairs broadcasts of campus speakers and forums. In February 2008, The Publications Board recognized the ''[[Dailyer Nebraskan]]'' as an affiliated publication and approved the printing costs of the first three issues of the satirical paper.[http://media.www.dailynebraskan.com/media/storage/paper857/news/2007/12/12/News/Dailyer.Nebraskan.Receives.Approval-3143119.shtml Dailyer Nebraskan receives approval - News] ==Notable alumni, faculty, and staff== {{Main|List of University of NebraskaâLincoln people}} Many of UNL alumni and alumnae have had considerable success in scientific research, public service, education, and business. As of 2011, 3 alumni have [[List of University of NebraskaâLincoln people#Nobel laureates|won the Nobel Prize]], 8 have won the [[Pulitzer Prize]], 22 have been selected as [[Rhodes Scholar]]s, 18 have been selected as [[Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship|Goldwater Scholar]]s and 11 have been selected as [[Truman Scholar]]s. ==In fiction and popular culture== ===Onscreen=== * [[Yes Man (film)|''Yes Man'' (2008 film)]] - filming took place, in part, at University of NebraskaâLincoln. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.unl.edu/ Official website] * [http://www.huskers.com/ Official athletics website] * [http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/ University of Nebraska press] {{University of Nebraska}} {{University of Nebraska-Lincoln}} {{Big Ten Conference}} {{Committee on Institutional Cooperation}} {{Colleges and universities in Nebraska}} {{Universities Research Association}} {{DEFAULTSORT:NebraskaâLincoln, University Of}} [[Category:University of NebraskaâLincoln| ]] [[Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities]] [[Category:Committee on Institutional Cooperation]] [[Category:Land-grant universities and colleges]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Nebraska]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1869]] [[Category:North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]] [[Category:Education in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:Flagship universities in the United States]] [[de:University of Nebraska-Lincoln]] [[es:Universidad de Nebraska-Lincoln]] [[fa:Ø¯Ø§ÙØ´Ú¯Ø§Ù ÙØ¨Ø±Ø§Ø³Ú©Ø§ Ø¯Ø± ÙÛÙÚ©ÙÙ]] [[fr:UniversitÃ© du NebraskaâLincoln]] [[ko:ë¤ë¸ëì¤ì¹´ ëíêµ ë§ì»¨]] [[ja:ããã©ã¹ã«å¤§å­¦ãªã³ã«ã¼ã³æ ¡]] [[pt:Universidade de Nebraska-Lincoln]] [[zh:åå¸ææ¯å å¤§å­¦æè¯åæ ¡]]
